block.p: The Chicago Board of Trade will appoint a task force next month to study the possibility of merging with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, but such a deal is not likely, according to Patrick Arbor, the Board of Trade's chairman.

The possible merger was one of several cost-cutting suggestions in an internal Board of Trade study reported in the latest Crain's Chicago Business, a weekly magazine. Mr. Arbor and many of the large trading houses that belong to both exchanges favor such a move, but there is also strong opposition.

The Chicago Board of Trade will appoint a task force next month to study the possibility of merging with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, but such a deal is not likely, according to Patrick Arbor, the Board of Trade's chairman.

The possible merger was one of several cost-cutting suggestions in an internal Board of Trade study reported in the latest Crain's Chicago Business, a weekly magazine. Mr. Arbor and many of the large trading houses that belong to both exchanges favor such a move, but there is also strong opposition.

Mr. Arbor said that he had recently discussed the idea informally with Jack Sandner, chairman of the Merc, but that the discussions were not as serious as those they had two years ago. The Merc has suffered a sharp decline in trading volumes on its crucial currency exchanges, with overall volume off 29 percent last year from 1994's record levels.
